content:
Just got a notification for this:
image.png
...should I press the button? :sweat_smile:
That looks promising to me. Is that a new feature, or is it something we've been aware of for a while?
New (beta) feature it seems.
What I meant was, is it new to you, or have you seen it before? (It's definitely new to me.)
New to me too ...here's a screencap: https://www.facebook.com/CoderHQ/videos/we-are-on-the-github-discussions-betaget-support-share-resources-post-your-proje/951774098624018/
https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/discussions
...seems to have the same "mark as accepted answer" feature as we have in our forum.
It would be nice to get on that "Communities using discussions" list. We could find some new recruits.

I'm just concerned it'll fragment discussions further between:

  • Issue queue
  • Forum
  • Zulip
@klonos Maybe open an issue in b.org repo to discuss further first...

I will do @BWPanda ...but only if I find it useful after all. It seems to me same as issues, but with different styling: https://github.com/cdr/code-server/discussions/2385

Do the same with Azure Data Studio · Discussion #2385 · cdr/code-server
VS Code in the browser. Contribute to cdr/code-server development by creating an account on GitHub.
oooh ...has threaded comments :thinking:

If that is an acceptable mode of discussion, what would be wrong with locking the forum and pushing this in favor of the forum? One less thing to maintain which frees up time to focus on other tasks.

Since it's in beta, I doubt they have an API, but maybe down the road there will be a way to tie that in with Backdropcms.org so it feels more "at home"

@Phil Ward I agree; I'd be ok using this instead of the forum (I feel using both would be duplication/distribution of efforts/discussions), however I believe one of the arguments for us having a forum is that it's easier for people to use who don't use/know GitHub (it's still primarily a developer tool)... Otherwise I'd be all for that.

I've never been a big GitHub user myself because I haven't had a need to use it. That said, if that's what BackdropCMS wants to use and I need to get more familiarized with it, then that's just how it is and it's time to learn more about it.

In my mind, what's the difference between creating an account for GitHub which gives me access to a lot of stuff not just backdrop, vs creating yet another account for a very pointed and specific purpose.

IIRC, I don't have an account on Backdrop yet because the main thing I can do with it is the forums. I hate traditional forums and do my best to stay away from them. Outside of the "everybody has the same problem and nobody has a fix", forums are just clunky to navigate and follow. Main point is, I have enough accounts to keep track of. I don't like adding to the list of I don't have to.

If I hop on the b.org forum and post an issue, I'm going to be redirected to create an issue on GitHub which means I still need a GitHub account in addition to a b.org account. I think a lot of people would appreciate not having two different accounts knowing they can accomplish everything through one platform.

Pros and cons to both... I'm not advocating either but hopefully my opinions on the matter will give some direction to thought.

Initial thoughts are: I like the idea of using one platform to discuss (almost) everything. Expanding on that thought, we do have zulip which is great for fast response and internal discussion.

If anyone looks into this, find out if a discussion can be converted over to an issue. How cool would it be to say "hey, this discussion is an actual problem that needs fixed. Let's move it to an issue so we can not only properly fix it, but keep track of the discussion that led us here"
I agree, there are pros and cons to both. I am concerned that we currently have to many places for discussions, but I can't see an easy solution to it.
Another "pro" for our current forum is that it works well with Google for finding answers to questions.
I view it as an important tool for outreach to beginners.

Regarding switching to GitHub discussions: IMO our forum is a good low-level entry point for less technical users. I've heard several times that GitHub is a bit intimidating for them.

Another thought: if we did everything via GitHub, we're pretty depending on it and a later switch to something else might become very hard, if not impossible. Having own infrastructure gives a little more control.
Plus it's a bit of eating our own dog food
This 'Discussions' discussion seems to have lost steam... Was an issue ever created for this, or do we just leave it?

I just don't have the energy for that discussion. Sorry. :-(

Something like Github discussions would solve some problems in our community while making new ones. I don't want to create a new place for discussions, unless it replaces an old one, and I'm not sure which of the old ones I willing to give up.

The most logical one to replace would be the forum, but I don't like the idea of replacing forum.backdropcms.org with a github forum. I could be convinced, but I'm not sure that I want to be.

I would say, rather than starting with Github forums as a solution to a problem that has not been clearly defined. Let's define the problem we are trying to solve so we can better evaluate whether or not Github forums would solve it.

Any ideas if the github discussions has an api to add/show the discussions outside of github?

If we could replace the forums with github discussions on forum.b.org it might be something worth pursuing down the road.
I agree with @StPaulTim. Let's start with a need rather than let the technology lead

The reason why I mentioned that new GitHub feature was because in the past people (I recall @docwilmot but could be others too) said that issues should start as discussions elsewhere, and only once we have a clear definition of what needs to be done we should open issues in GitHub. ...so I thought that GitHub discussions could be that place.
@klonos - I'd be more receptive to that use of Github discussions than as a replacement for the forum. Still not sure that it really buys us much, but it might.
I may play around with them a little in my own repo and see what I think.

I think we should seriously consider it if:

1) we can potentially replace the current forums with the git discussion but still allow it to live on b.org.

2) we can convert a discussion into an issue.

I came in to echo @Herb ‘s point: there’s something to the point that the forum is using our own technology, and is therefore an example of eating our own dog food.

I’d like to extend that if possible — we should have instructions easily available on how people could create their own version of the forum. (Perhaps there already is, and I don’t know where to find it? I know I’ve been shown how to do it before, but I think that required my behind-the-scenes access.)

@Luke McCormick (cellear) Instructions here: https://github.com/backdrop-ops/forum.backdropcms.org
